metadata.name: Klyft #400
metadata.description:
‚ÄúKlyft‚Äù is part of the fxhash interactive minting experience at PARIS+ par Art Basel.

Klyft is a juxtaposition of two different projections for the future. One, made by the World Economic Forum, suggests that the global gender gap will have closed by the year 2154. The other, by the UN IPCC, estimates that global warming will reach 3.2 degrees celcius by the year 2100.

Klyft makes use of the unique temporal aspect of computational art by developing its expression gradually over the next 132 years. As we come closer to 2154, the space between the two shapes in Klyft will grow smaller to symbolize the closing of the gender gap. As time goes on, however, Klyft also becomes more and more glitched out to represent the projected increases in greenhouse gases and climate catastrophes.

In the end, Klyft‚Äôs expression will be heavily corrupted, and the two shapes will have reached each other.

¬∑ URL parameters ¬∑

You can add the following parameters to the URL to change the behavior of the piece.

date=<YYYY-MM-DD> ‚Äî See how Klyft looks on another day. Use the format YYYY-MM-DD. 

color=<number> ‚Äî See the piece in another color scheme. The numbers loop around, so 17 equals 0, 18 equals 1, etc. 

resolution=<number> ‚Äî View the piece in a higher resolution. 1 is normal resolution, 2 is double, etc. No decimals allowed.

image=true ‚Äî Save the piece as an image. 

record=true ‚Äî Save the piece as a video in WEBM format.

Adding the following URL parameters will show Klyft in double resolution on the day gender equality is achieved according to the WEF:

date=2154-01-01&resolution=2

Adding the following URL parameters will save a video of Klyft in the ‚ÄòStokkendahl Dalgas‚Äô color scheme:

color=14&record=true

¬∑ Interactions ¬∑

Pressing the following keys will trigger functionality as well as add related URL parameters automatically. 

Pressing D will increment the date by 1 year.

Pressing C will increment the color index by 1.

Pressing R will toggle between normal and double resolution.

Pressing I will toggle the image URL parameter, which saves the piece as an image. Only works outside of iframe.

Pressing V will toggle the video URL parameter, which saves the piece as a video. Only works outside of iframe.

There are secret key presses as well. Some of them only work outside of iframe. 

¬∑ Accessibility ¬∑

Klyft is built to support screen readers. It has been tested using MacOS‚Äô VoiceOver, and uses p5.js‚Äô describeElement() to provide screen reader functionality.

If you have any comments (good or bad) on the screen reader integration, don‚Äôt hesitate to reach out on my Twitter: @ada_ada_ada_art. 

¬∑ Credits and license ¬∑

Klyft is made with p5.js.

Klyft is licensed under a modified version of the Climate Strike License (CSL).

metadata.name: SENTINELS #3
metadata.description:
The SENTINELS, with their cold, diamond forms, reign over an unsettling realm. Their presence exudes an aura of solemn guardianship, shrouded with unease. These are not friendly guides; they are silent arbiters of the unknown, both protectors and judges of the enigma that is their terrain. As you gaze into their world, let these haunting apparitions remind you of the vastness of the cosmos. 

The SENTINELS beckon you to explore the sinister beauty of the abyss, to question, and to wander through a digital realm where the eerie and the captivating coexist.

Paranoia is a necessary skill whenever a SENTINEL is involved.
 
SENTINELS is not only an exploration of the sublime-it also empowers collectors to generate physical artifacts from the void. With a keystroke, you choose your format:

Press ‚Äòs‚Äô or ‚Äò1‚Äô to save a compact version
‚Äò2‚Äô for a print-ready image
‚Äò3‚Äô for a high-resolution image

metadata.name: linear segmentarity #57
metadata.description:
‚ÄúWe are segmented from all around and in every direction. The human being is a segmentary animal. Segmentarity is inherent to all the strata composing us. Dwelling, getting around, working, playing: life is spatially and socially segmented. The house is segmented according to its rooms‚Äô assigned purposes; streets, according to the order of the city; the factory, according to the nature of the work and operations performed in it. We are segmented in a binary fashion, following the great major dualist oppositions: social classes, but also men-women, adult-children, and so on.‚Äù 

-a thousand plateaus: capitalism and schizophrenia, Deleuze and Guattari

Linear Segmentarity explores the concept of a segmented existence, which refers to how our lives are broken up into discreet parts or segments.

I was inspired by the philosophers Deleuze and Guattari. These thinkers studied the ways we are segmented into work and play, family and friends, and past and present. We move through our days in a series of linear segments, each one leading to the next. 

Each segment has its territory with its own rules and way of doing things. We are constantly shifting from one to the next, and the sum of these segments defines our existence. 

Art can help us visualize this hidden aspect of ourselves and feel its impact. Using Javascript to describe the sporadic nature of the world, this project invites us to see the linear segmentarity at work in our environment.

metadata.name: Abstract Temples #11
metadata.description:
Giorgio de Chirico was a prominent influence on the Surrealist movement. De Chirico‚Äôs art portrays dream-like and distorted worlds that encourage viewers to explore their subconscious. 

I am fascinated by the different ways artists have found to express esoteric concepts. In particular, I am interested in how artists like Giorgio de Chirico have used light and color to create ethereal images. 

I believe that the Abstract Temples project is a perfect example of how generative art can be used to create metaphysical artwork. By invoking the visual language of the dream world, these images invite you to explore the nebulous relationship between external and internal space.

In addition to the influence of Giorgio de Chirico, I would also like to credit James Turrell as an inspiration for this project. Turrell is an artist who creates installations that play with our perception of light and space. Turrell‚Äôs work has profoundly impacted my understanding of how art can create an immersive and disorienting experience. 

Each temple room is randomly generated from a selection of 16 templates. The templates include a variety of randomized features, including the color palette, celestial objects, design variations, and other effects. They also contain a rare secret. 

This project was created with p5js. 

Features:
-16 room templates
-18 color palettes
-Celestial objects
-Secrets

metadata.name: Paper Noise #3
metadata.description:
This series is about finding the beauty in discarded things. It's about seeing the potential for art in the most unexpected places and creating something new from what already exists.

One thing we love about art is that it can be a direct expression of our thoughts and feelings. But what about the happy accidents that can happen when we let go and allow the materials to guide us?

I love the serendipitous moments that arise when I relinquish control, letting the materials show me the way. The printmaking process can be messy and unpredictable. I often use sheets of notebook paper to keep my workspace clean. When I‚Äôm done, I save some of the scrap sheets of paper. 

The mark of a dirty brayer, drips of paint, a coffee stain, or a ripped edge can all be embraced as part of the final composition. A similar process happens in generative art, where projects can have near limitless possibilities.

Sheets of paper can represent many things: a blank slate, an adventure, or even noise. This project is dedicated to all the leftovers and forgotten things in the world. It's a reminder that even the smallest piece of paper can be beautiful.

metadata.name: The Emoji Finder Game üîé #126
metadata.description:
This is a 'Where's Waldo'-like video game(!) that procedurally generates one of seven fun and hectic "biomes" to search through. Find the specified emoji before time runs out to win! 

The seven biomes are: Safari, Ocean, Space, Kitchen, Twitter, Forest, and City. Share your game links with friends! 

Created by Michael Perusse | https://twitter.com/mrperusse

metadata.name: K√§ppygen #35
metadata.description: Chaotic bursts of vertexes

metadata.name: Calmer waters - reissue #4
metadata.description:
This is a reissue of project #10669
https://www.fxhash.xyz/generative/10669

I long for calmer waters. This piece is about that. It's a counterpoint. It reflects some of my best memories of the sea: the warm salty air on my face, interspersed with a cool breeze, leaving my lips salty tasting. The gentle rushing of the water. 

The sea with its vast panorama's can make you feel insignificant in the grand scheme of things. But this piece is about hope.
///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
About this reissue: An update of the security policy of fx(hash) blocks external scripts. This update stops malicious actors; they could try to interact with a user‚Äôs wallet. So, this update is really a good thing. It‚Äôs a safeguard. However, due to this update the original project no longer loads in live view and after consultation and deliberation I decided to reissue the token without the use of external scripts (p5js). 

Only holders of the original project are on the allow list. 

Royalties are for the minter.

attributes.name: Features?
attributes.value: Only pixels colored with code, love and gratitude

attributes.name: Suggested accompanying audio
attributes.value: Max Richter: Dream 3 in the midst of my life (Sleep)

metadata.name: HOWL.camera #113
metadata.description:
Created with the permission and endorsement of Allen Ginsberg's estate, enabled by theVERSEverse, this work channels Ginsberg's iconic poem HOWL through a dynamic ASCII lens.

Written by Ross Goodwin using 54 of Ginsberg's original photographs and a Markov language model of HOWL in vanilla JS. Each edition shifts from the minter's chosen photograph after 10 seconds into pure ASCII noise, eventually devolving into chaotic Markov fragments.

60% of mint and royalty proceeds will be donated to benefit victims of the recent Los Angeles fires.

https://howl.camera

metadata.name: [WAITING TO BE SIGNED]
metadata.description: This Gentk is waiting to be signed by Fxhash Signer module

metadata.name: Winesburg, Ohio #9
metadata.description: ‚ÄúWinesburg, Ohio‚Äù is an act of uncanny place-making. The collection borrows its name from a 1919 short-story cycle by Sherwood Anderson, which explores a peculiar cast of characters living within a fictionalized, midwestern town. Like Anderson‚Äôs text, the ‚ÄúWinesburg, Ohio‚Äù algorithm constructs a world through recurring portrayals of specific structures and landmarks. Its scenes are populated by a variety of familiar elements taken from my larger body of work, including water towers, houses, and churches. Meanwhile, a series of scripted gestures insert abstract compositional elements into the outputs, counteracting their pictorial legibility. The strange landscapes that result are composite ideograms, comprised of multiple spatial possibilities that co-exist in varying states of contradiction.

metadata.name: Vanishing Horizons #31
metadata.description:
"I never wanted color to be color. I never wanted texture to be texture, or images to become shapes. I wanted them all to fuse together into a living spirit." - Clyfford Still


I have spent most of my life residing in urban environments. While figurative art is not a style I typically pursue in my own work, I delight in discovering abstract elements within it. The cities I've inhabited have consistently offered me the chance to do so through their architectural landscapes.

Le Corbusier once said that a metropolis's abstract skyline serves as its autobiography, etched in steel and glass, unveiling its history, character, and ambitions. In this series, my aim has been to encapsulate that sentiment using a minimalistic canvas and a monochromatic palette. Abstract expressionism remains my lens for viewing every artwork. 

The style of this series is my homage to Clyfford Still, an abex artist I have always admired. His ability to convey profound meaning through seemingly empty and unfilled canvases has always intrigued me. 

Implemented in JS, this code utilizes the Perlin.js and Simple-noise.js libraries.

Press s to save the image in full screen. 

Pixel Love!

metadata.name: Robotics #82
metadata.description:
Robotics by Hevey (@HeveyArt).

This artwork was created using p5js.

metadata.name: Splash on Tezos #9

Splash on Tezos - Animated minimalism using a soft color palette.
Splash and soft delicate color bends shaped into endless motion.

metadata.name: fx cubes #5
metadata.description:
First minting of cubes oscillating in space, black and white.
The more iterations minted, the more cubes are created.
600x600px, made in p5js by Damien Borowik.
More info at dborowik.com
